What is a Gaussian random variable?
cards.back: A random variable following the normal (bell-curve) distribution, characterized by mean μ and variance σ².

cards.front: In y(t) = x(t) + n(t), what does n(t) represent?
cards.back: Noise — the random component added by the channel or system.

cards.front: Why is most real-world noise Gaussian?
cards.back: Central Limit Theorem: sum of many small independent effects tends to Gaussian distribution.

cards.front: What does it mean for a random process to be stationary?
cards.back: Its statistical properties (mean, variance, autocorrelation) don't change over time.

cards.front: Is a periodic signal deterministic or random?
cards.back: Deterministic. If it repeats exactly, you can predict all future values.
